unnormalised: The annual Diwali sale at Chandni Chowk was usually a chaotic but joyful affair. But this year, the numbers told a different story. The saree shop owned by Mr. Rajesh, "Shringar Sarees," had seen a dip of almost 20% in sales compared to last year. He attributed it to the rising prices of raw materials, pushing the cost of a Banarasi saree to ₹12,000 from ₹10,000 last year.
normalised: The annual Diwali sale at Chandni Chowk was usually a chaotic but joyful affair. But this year, the numbers told a different story. The saree shop owned by Mister Rajesh, "Shringar Sarees," had seen a dip of almost twenty percent in sales compared to last year. He attributed it to the rising prices of raw materials, pushing the cost of a Banarasi saree to rupee twelve thousand from rupee ten thousand last year.

unnormalised: Across the street, at "Gupta Electronics," the situation wasn't much brighter. Despite offering a 15% discount on all televisions, Mr. Gupta managed to sell only 50 units, down from 65 last Diwali. He blamed the online retailers, "Amazon and Flipkart are offering similar products at 5-10% lower rates. How can a small shop like mine compete?"

unnormalised: Even the sweet shops, traditionally bustling during Diwali, felt the pinch. "Haldiram's Sweets," a popular outlet, reported a decline of 12% in their mithai sales. They had increased the price of their famous 'Kaju Katli' to Rs. 800 per kg, which probably deterred some customers. Mrs. Sharma, a regular customer, said, "I usually buy 2 kg, but this year, I'll just get 1 kg. Budget constraints, you see."

unnormalised: The street food vendors, though always in demand, experienced a subtle shift. A plate of 'pani puri,' which used to cost ₹20, now costs ₹25. The vendor, Raju, explained, "The price of everything, from potatoes to spices, has gone up. I have no choice but to increase the price."

unnormalised: For Mr. Rajesh, Mr. Gupta, and countless other small business owners in Chandni Chowk, the Diwali sales figures served as a wake-up call.
